The announcement must be confirmed through official government channels or documentation. In the absence of a direct government announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, El País, Reuters, Bloomberg) are sufficient. Minor policy adjustments or reaffirmations of existing policies do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major political debate or policy in the next decade be influenced by scientific research on black holes?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2033, a major political debate or policy decision in any country is significantly influenced by scientific research on black holes. Influence is defined as the explicit citation of black hole research in the formulation, debate, or justification of the policy or debate. The policy or debate must be recognized as 'major' by being covered in at least three reputable news sources (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, etc.) or being the subject of a legislative or executive action at the national level. The influence of black hole research must be explicitly acknowledged in the policy documentation, legislative records, or by statements from at least three prominent politicians or policymakers involved in the debate or policy formulation. In the absence of explicit acknowledgment, a consensus among at least three experts in political science or astrophysics, as reported in reputable scientific or major news outlets, that the research had a significant impact on the policy or debate, will also result in a Yes resolution.

title: Will a major political figure propose significant reforms to pharmaceutical regulations by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure has publicly proposed significant reforms to pharmaceutical regulations. A "major political figure" is defined as a current head of state, government leader, or a minister of health in any of the G20 countries. "Significant reforms" are defined as proposed changes that would substantially alter the approval process, pricing, distribution, or patent laws of pharmaceutical products. The proposal must be made in an official capacity, and must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Proposals made in personal capacities or without formal announcement do not count. In the event of multiple proposals, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first proposal meeting these criteria.

title: Will the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announce a new pandemic-level outbreak by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) officially announces a new pandemic-level outbreak. A pandemic-level outbreak is defined as an epidemic of a disease that has spread across a large region, for instance multiple continents or worldwide, with sustained person-to-person transmission, leading to widespread illness. The announcement must be made through an official CDC press release or public statement. In the absence of a direct announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) confirming the CDC's classification of an outbreak as pandemic-level will also be considered sufficient for resolution. Temporary alerts or warnings about potential outbreaks do not count towards this question's resolution.

metadata.tags: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Will Tesla announce a major initiative to influence environmental policy in any country by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Tesla, Inc. has officially announced a major initiative aimed at influencing environmental policy in any country. A "major initiative" is defined as a program, partnership, or action with substantial investment or impact, intended to shape or significantly alter environmental policy or regulations. The announcement must be made through official Tesla channels or verified by Elon Musk directly. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Initiatives focused solely on product launches or enhancements do not count towards this question's resolution. In the event of ambiguous announcements, the question will resolve based on the consensus of coverage by the specified news organizations.

title: Will Spain lead a significant reform in the European Union's health policy by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Spain has led a significant reform in the European Union's health policy. A "significant reform" is defined as a change or series of changes to the EU's health policy that are widely recognized as having a substantial impact on health outcomes, health care delivery, or health governance within the EU member states. The reform must be initiated by Spain and must receive formal approval by the European Union through its legislative or executive decision-making bodies, such as the European Parliament, the European Council, or the European Commission. Confirmation of such a reform must come from official EU announcements or documentation. In the absence of direct announcements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. Temporary measures or proposals that have not received formal approval do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major political figure publicly endorse basketball as a tool for social change by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure has publicly endorsed basketball as a tool for social change. A "major political figure" is defined as a current or former head of state, government, or a member of the cabinet (or equivalent executive body) of any country recognized by the United Nations. The endorsement must be explicit, referring directly to basketball's role in promoting social change, and must be made in a public forum such as an official speech, published article, or through verified social media accounts. The endorsement must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of ambiguous statements, the resolution will consider the context and intent behind the endorsement. Temporary or casual mentions without a clear endorsement do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will Formula 1 influence any major political decisions or policies in the next 5 years?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, there is verifiable evidence that Formula 1 has directly influenced a major political decision or policy in any country. A "major political decision or policy" is defined as one that has a significant impact on national legislation, international relations, environmental regulations, or economic strategies. The influence of Formula 1 must be explicitly acknowledged by the decision-making body or through credible documentation. Verification can come from official government statements, legislative documents, or reports from at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary or minor policy adjustments, such as local traffic regulations for race events, do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major political scandal related to ethics emerge globally before 2025?
Will Taiwan declare formal independence from China before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, Taiwan officially declares independence from China through a formal announcement by the President of Taiwan or a legislative act passed by the Legislative Yuan of Taiwan. The declaration must be recognized internationally by at least three UN member states. In the absence of a formal declaration, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) confirming the declaration will also be considered sufficient. This question resolves as NO if no such declaration is made or recognized by the specified date. Temporary or symbolic declarations without international recognition or subsequent retraction do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will South Korea hold a referendum on reunification with North Korea before 2026?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2026, South Korea officially announces and holds a referendum on the reunification with North Korea. The referendum must be a nationwide vote, open to all eligible voters in South Korea, specifically addressing the issue of reunifying with North Korea. The announcement of the referendum must come from an official government source, such as the South Korean government's official website or public statements from the President of South Korea or relevant government ministers. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the scheduling and execution of the referendum will be sufficient for resolution. Temporary or informal polls, surveys, or public opinions do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will NASA announce a significant space policy initiative with direct implications for international relations by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, NASA announces a significant space policy initiative that has direct implications for international relations. The initiative must be a new policy or a substantial amendment to an existing policy that affects international cooperation, competition, or conflict in space exploration, utilization, or security. The announcement must be made through official NASA channels, including press releases, official statements, or public-facing documents. In the absence of a direct announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. The policy initiative must be clearly intended to be implemented, not merely proposed or under consideration. In the event of ambiguity regarding the policy's implications for international relations, a consensus among at least three reputable space policy analysts or experts will be required for resolution.

title: Will a major political figure cite string theory in a policy speech or public statement by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure has cited string theory in a policy speech or public statement. A "major political figure" is defined as a current or former head of state, government, or a member of the cabinet (or equivalent executive body) of any of the G20 nations. The citation of string theory must be explicit, referring to it by name or describing its fundamental concepts in a manner that clearly indicates string theory. The statement or speech must be public and verifiable through official channels or reputable media outlets such as BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, or Reuters. In the event that multiple political figures cite string theory, the resolution will be based on the first verified instance. If there is ambiguity in the citation's reference to string theory, a consensus of at least three experts in theoretical physics or political analysis, reported by reputable news sources, will be required to resolve the question.

title: Will a new global health policy emerge as a result of epidemiological findings by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a new global health policy is officially adopted or recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) or a similar authoritative global health body as a direct result of epidemiological findings. The policy must be aimed at addressing a significant health issue and must be adopted by at least 5 countries or have a clear implementation plan involving multiple countries. The adoption of the policy must be confirmed by official documentation or announcements from the WHO or the respective health bodies of the adopting countries. In the absence of direct announcements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient to confirm the policy's adoption. The policy must be new, not an amendment or extension of existing policies, and must be based on epidemiological findings published after January 1, 2020.

title: Will a major political figure in the US test positive for a significant infectious disease before the next presidential election?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before the date of the next U.S. presidential election, a major political figure in the United States tests positive for a significant infectious disease. For the purposes of this question, a "major political figure" is defined as the President, Vice President, any member of the U.S. Cabinet, any member of the U.S. Senate or House of Representatives, or any Governor of a U.S. state.

A "significant infectious disease" is defined as one that is classified as such by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) at the time of diagnosis. Confirmation of the positive test must come from an official statement by the political figure themselves, their office, or a reputable news source (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post).

In the event that multiple political figures test positive, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first confirmed case. If no such case is confirmed before the next presidential election, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will the Democratic Party (US) introduce a major healthcare reform bill focused on infectious diseases before the end of 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the Democratic Party in the United States Congress introduces a major healthcare reform bill specifically focused on infectious diseases. A "major healthcare reform bill" is defined as legislation that proposes significant changes or additions to existing healthcare policies, funding, or infrastructure related to the prevention, treatment, or management of infectious diseases. The bill must be officially introduced in either the House of Representatives or the Senate and must be focused primarily on infectious diseases, rather than being a broader healthcare bill with sections pertaining to infectious diseases. The introduction of the bill must be confirmed by official congressional records. In the absence of a direct announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, Washington Post, CNN) will be considered sufficient evidence. In the event of multiple bills being introduced, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one bill meets the above criteria.

title: Will a member of the US Congress propose legislation to limit or regulate political sponsorships in sports, including Formula 1, by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a member of the US Congress has officially proposed legislation aimed at limiting or regulating political sponsorships in sports, including but not limited to Formula 1. The proposal must seek to directly address the visibility, presence, or financial influence of political entities or messages within sports sponsorships. The legislation must be formally introduced in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. Confirmation of such a proposal can come from official congressional records, announcements, or credible news sources such as BBC, The New York Times, Washington Post, or Reuters. In the event that multiple proposals are introduced, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first proposal's introduction. Proposals that are purely symbolic, without a clear path to becoming law, do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a candidate from Virginia win a major party nomination for the 2024 Presidential election?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, a candidate with established residency in Virginia at the time of their nomination wins the nomination of either the Democratic or Republican party for the 2024 Presidential election. The candidate must be officially recognized as the nominee by their respective party. Confirmation of the candidate's residency and nomination status must be reported by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post, CNN). In the event of a contested nomination or any ambiguity regarding the official nominee, the question will resolve based on the candidate who is recognized as the nominee by the majority of the aforementioned news organizations. This question does not consider independent or third-party candidates.

title: Will a current or former NBA player announce a candidacy for a political office in the US by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, any current or former NBA player officially announces their candidacy for any political office within the United States. The announcement must be made through an official campaign launch or a formal declaration of intent to run for office. Verification will be based on reports from reputable news sources such as ESPN, The New York Times, The Washington Post, or official statements from the candidate's campaign. In the event of an ambiguous announcement, the question will resolve as Yes only if the candidacy is confirmed by the individual or their official campaign within 30 days of the initial announcement. For the purpose of this question, 'political office' refers to any elected position at the federal, state, or local level.

title: Will FIFA introduce a new policy aimed at increasing transparency in football governance before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, FIFA officially announces and implements a new policy aimed at increasing transparency in football governance. The policy must address at least one of the following areas: financial transparency, election processes, or decision-making processes. The announcement must be made through official FIFA communication channels or documented in FIFA's official records. In the absence of a direct announcement, confirmation from at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. The policy must be in effect and not merely proposed or under consideration. In the event of a policy aimed at a specific area of governance, the question will resolve as Yes only if the policy is intended for application across all levels of FIFA governance.

title: Will a major political figure propose a bill to recognize tennis as a national sport in any country by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure in any country has officially proposed a bill to recognize tennis as a national sport. A "major political figure" is defined as a member of the national government, such as a president, prime minister, cabinet member, or member of the national legislature. The proposal must be formally submitted for consideration to the relevant legislative body or officially announced in a national government publication or press release. In the absence of a formal submission, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the proposal will suffice. The bill does not need to be passed or come into effect for the question to resolve as Yes.

title: Will Italy pass a significant electoral reform aimed at reducing political fragmentation before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, Italy passes a significant electoral reform aimed at reducing political fragmentation within its parliamentary system. Significant electoral reform is defined as any legal or constitutional change that alters the electoral system with the explicit goal of reducing the number of political parties in the Parliament or facilitating the formation of more stable governments. The reform must be passed by the Italian Parliament and come into effect before the resolution date. Confirmation must come from official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary measures or reforms limited to specific regions or electoral events do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will there be a significant policy change in the United Kingdom regarding the regulation of pharmaceuticals by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United Kingdom has officially announced and implemented a significant policy change regarding the regulation of pharmaceuticals. A "significant policy change" is defined as any new law, amendment, or regulatory adjustment that materially affects the approval, distribution, pricing, or advertising of pharmaceutical products within the UK. The change must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The policy change must be in effect, not merely proposed or under consideration. Minor adjustments or clarifications to existing regulations do not qualify as significant for the purpose of this question.

title: Will a major political figure propose a global initiative to combat a new infectious disease by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major political figure proposes a global initiative to combat a new infectious disease. A "major political figure" is defined as a current or former head of state, government, or an international organization (e.g., United Nations, World Health Organization). The disease must be one that emerged or was identified after 2023. The proposal must call for international cooperation and be aimed at preventing, managing, or eradicating the disease. The initiative must be publicized through an official announcement or press release. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The initiative must not be a continuation or rebranding of existing efforts but must represent a new strategy or approach. In the event of multiple proposals, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

title: Will the US dollar lose its status as the world's primary reserve currency by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the US dollar is no longer the world's primary reserve currency. The primary reserve currency is defined as the currency that holds the largest share of officially held foreign exchange reserves. This status change must be confirmed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) or the World Bank. Reports from reputable financial news sources such as The Financial Times, Bloomberg, or The Economist, corroborating the IMF or World Bank's announcement, will also be considered. In the event of a close margin between the US dollar and the next leading currency, the question will resolve as Yes only if the US dollar's share is less than 50% of total global reserves.

title: Will a political debate or campaign prominently feature sports, specifically tennis, as a key topic by 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a political debate or campaign within any country prominently features sports, specifically tennis, as a key topic. 

To "prominently feature" means that tennis must be discussed or mentioned as a significant part of the campaign or debate agenda, not merely in passing. This can include, but is not limited to, policy proposals, public endorsements by prominent tennis figures, or significant funding commitments towards tennis-related initiatives. 

Confirmation must come from official campaign materials, statements from the candidates or their representatives, or coverage in at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). 

In the event that multiple campaigns or debates meet these criteria, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one does so by the specified date. Temporary or one-off mentions related to specific events do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the United Kingdom hold another referendum on Scottish independence before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, the United Kingdom officially announces or holds a referendum on Scottish independence. The announcement must come from a recognized authority within the UK government, such as the Prime Minister's Office, the Parliament, or the Scottish Government. The referendum must be legally sanctioned and scheduled to occur, with a clear question regarding Scottish independence presented to voters. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the scheduling of such a referendum will suffice for resolution. Temporary or advisory referendums, or polls not sanctioned by the UK government, do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the Republican Party win the presidency in the next US election?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if the Republican Party candidate wins the majority of the Electoral College votes in the next United States presidential election, as officially certified by the U.S. Congress. The resolution will be based on the official certification of the election results by Congress, not on preliminary election night counts or media projections. In the event of any legal challenges that delay certification, the question will resolve based on the outcome of the final legal decision. If the election results are contested and lead to a situation where no candidate is declared the winner by Congress by January 20 following the election, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will Israel announce a significant shift in its foreign policy towards Iran by 2025?
Will any major political figure in the world of tennis publicly advocate for significant new measures to combat climate change before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, any individual recognized as a major political figure in the world of tennis (such as heads of major tennis organizations, presidents of tennis federations, or individuals holding equivalent positions) publicly advocates for significant new measures to combat climate change. Significant new measures include, but are not limited to, substantial policy proposals, funding initiatives, or public campaigns aimed at reducing carbon emissions, promoting renewable energy, or enhancing sustainability within the sport of tennis or beyond. The advocacy must be verifiable through official statements, public records, or credible news reports from reputable sources such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, or Washington Post. In the event of ambiguous statements, the resolution will consider the context and intent behind the statements to determine if they advocate for significant new measures against climate change. Temporary or minor initiatives, such as single-event campaigns or small-scale local efforts, do not qualify for this question's resolution.

title: Will Ukraine hold national elections before the end of 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, Ukraine holds national elections. National elections are defined as presidential, parliamentary, or both, involving the general electorate of Ukraine. The elections must be officially recognized by the Central Election Commission of Ukraine and reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of postponement or cancellation, the question will resolve as No unless elections are rescheduled and successfully held before the specified date. Interim or emergency elections, if held as official national elections, will count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major political agreement on renewable energy be signed by over 30 countries before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major political agreement on renewable energy is signed by over 30 countries. A "major political agreement" is defined as an international treaty or accord that commits its signatories to specific targets or actions aimed at significantly increasing the use or production of renewable energy sources, such as solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy. The agreement must be recognized by the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) or a similar authoritative international body. The count of countries includes only sovereign states recognized by the United Nations. Signatures must be from authorized representatives of the signing countries, and the agreement must be open for ratification or already ratified by the signatories. In the event of disputes over the agreement's significance or the number of signatories, the resolution will defer to the UNFCCC or the designated authoritative body's official announcement.

title: Will a major political figure advocate for increased funding in particle physics research by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure publicly advocates for increased funding in particle physics research. A "major political figure" is defined as a current or former head of state, government, or a member of the cabinet (or equivalent executive body) of any of the G20 nations. Public advocacy must be clearly aimed at increasing government or private sector funding specifically for particle physics research and must be documented through an official statement, speech, or publication. The advocacy must be explicit in its support for particle physics research, not general scientific or research funding. In the event of ambiguous statements, the resolution will default to No. Verification will rely on reports from reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or official government publications.

title: Will Brazil introduce a significant policy change regarding its stance on climate change before 2025?
Will a new COVID-19 variant that leads to global travel restrictions be identified before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a new COVID-19 variant is identified that leads to the implementation of global travel restrictions. Global travel restrictions are defined as travel bans or mandatory quarantines affecting travelers from at least 100 countries, as announced by the World Health Organization (WHO), or a similar level of restrictions implemented by a coalition of at least five G7 countries. The identification of the variant must be confirmed by the WHO or through publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal. The implementation of travel restrictions must be reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, Reuters, or The Washington Post).

title: Will the Olympics lead to a significant shift in international political relations by 2025?
Will Russia face new international sanctions related to its political actions by 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Russia faces new international sanctions specifically related to its political actions. For the purpose of this question, "international sanctions" are defined as punitive measures imposed by one or more countries or international bodies (such as the United Nations, European Union, or other international coalitions) against the Russian Federation. These sanctions must be in response to actions deemed to violate international law or norms, including but not limited to military aggression, interference in the internal affairs of other countries, or violations of human rights.

The imposition of sanctions must be confirmed by official statements or documentation from the imposing entity or entities. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) will be considered sufficient evidence. Sanctions that are extensions or expansions of existing measures do not count unless they introduce significant new restrictions or targets.

This question will resolve as No if the specified conditions are not met by the resolution date.

title: Will a major political figure take up golf as a significant part of their public persona by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure has taken up golf as a significant part of their public persona. A "major political figure" is defined as a current or former head of state, head of government, or a politician holding a significant office (e.g., cabinet member, senator, member of parliament) in a G20 country. Taking up golf as a "significant part of their public persona" means that the individual is frequently seen playing golf, participates in public golfing events, discusses golf in interviews or on social media, or is otherwise publicly associated with the sport in a manner that is a notable aspect of their identity. Confirmation can come from public statements, media reports, or visual evidence from reputable news sources (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, etc.). In the event of ambiguity, a consensus of reports from at least three reputable news sources will be required for resolution.

title: Will there be a significant political scandal involving ethical misconduct by a major political figure before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a significant political scandal involving ethical misconduct by a major political figure is publicly disclosed. A "major political figure" is defined as a current or former head of state, government official at the cabinet level, or a leader of a major political party in any of the G7 countries (United States, United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy, Canada, Japan). Ethical misconduct includes, but is not limited to, corruption, abuse of power, significant conflict of interest, or criminal behavior directly related to their political duties. The scandal must be reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) and involve evidence or allegations that are considered credible by these sources. In the event of conflicting reports about the veracity of the allegations, the question will resolve as Yes only if the majority of these sources maintain the credibility of the allegations over a period of at least one month. Temporary or minor controversies do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the United States enter into a new nuclear agreement with Iran before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the United States and Iran officially enter into a new nuclear agreement. The agreement must be confirmed by an official announcement from either the U.S. Department of State or the Iranian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient to confirm the agreement. The agreement must be new, not an extension or modification of existing agreements. In the event of a dispute over the novelty of the agreement, the question will resolve based on the consensus of reports from the aforementioned news organizations. Temporary agreements or preliminary agreements not intended to be permanent do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will SpaceX's advancements in reusable launch systems significantly impact global space policy by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, SpaceX's advancements in reusable launch systems have led to significant changes in global space policy. Significant impact is defined as:
- The adoption of new international agreements or amendments to existing treaties that specifically address or are influenced by reusable launch technology.
- The establishment of new global standards or guidelines for space missions that prioritize or significantly incorporate reusable launch systems.
- A measurable increase in the number of countries or space agencies adopting reusable launch technologies for their space missions, as reported by reputable sources.

The impact must be confirmed by official documentation from international space organizations (e.g., United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs, International Astronautical Federation) or by credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Temporary or speculative impacts do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the United Kingdom hold another referendum on its EU membership by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the United Kingdom has officially announced and held another referendum on its membership in the European Union. The referendum must be a nationwide vote, asking the population whether the UK should remain outside of the EU, rejoin the EU, or renegotiate its EU membership terms. The resolution will be based on the official announcement of the referendum date by the UK government or a recognized electoral body. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the referendum has been scheduled or has taken place will suffice. Temporary or advisory referendums, or polls not sanctioned by the UK government, do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a candidate from a major party announce a groundbreaking policy proposal related to machine learning before the 2024 US elections?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, a candidate from either the Democratic or Republican party officially announces a groundbreaking policy proposal related to machine learning. A "groundbreaking policy proposal" is defined as a policy that significantly alters the current legal, ethical, or operational framework surrounding machine learning technologies in the United States. The announcement must be made through official campaign channels or during a public campaign event. For verification, the policy proposal must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the case of ambiguity regarding the groundbreaking nature of the proposal, a consensus among three experts in machine learning policy, interviewed by any of the aforementioned news organizations, will be required for resolution. Proposals that merely extend existing policies without significant innovation will not be considered groundbreaking. In the event that multiple candidates announce qualifying proposals, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first such announcement.

title: Will a major political party in any country officially reject climate change science by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, any major political party in any country officially rejects the science behind climate change. A "major political party" is defined as one that holds at least 5% of the seats in the national legislature or has received at least 5% of the vote in the most recent national election. An official rejection must be a public statement, policy, or platform position that explicitly denies the scientific consensus on climate change, as defined by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The rejection must be confirmed by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of ambiguous statements, the question will resolve as No unless there is clear consensus among the cited news sources that the party's position constitutes an official rejection.

title: Will France introduce a significant policy change regarding climate change by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, France has officially introduced a significant policy change regarding climate change. A "significant policy change" is defined as any new law, regulation, or official government action that represents a substantial shift in France's approach to addressing climate change, including but not limited to: - The implementation of a carbon tax or emissions trading system that covers a significant portion of France's carbon emissions. - A major investment in renewable energy sources or infrastructure that significantly increases France's renewable energy capacity. - Substantial changes in regulations or incentives that significantly affect the production, consumption, or conservation of energy. The introduction of such a policy must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. In the event of a minor policy adjustment or the continuation of existing policies, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will a global pandemic caused by a new infectious disease emerge before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new infectious disease causes a global pandemic. A "global pandemic" is defined as an outbreak of a disease that results in widespread illness across multiple countries or continents, officially declared as a pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO). The disease must be new, meaning it has not been previously identified in humans. The declaration by the WHO, or in its absence, a consensus among leading global health authorities (e.g., CDC, ECDC) will be considered conclusive evidence. In the event of conflicting reports, the question will resolve based on the majority opinion of these authorities. Temporary or localized outbreaks do not meet the criteria for this question's resolution.

title: Will a major breakthrough in biology influence global politics by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major breakthrough in biology is widely recognized to have significantly influenced global politics. A "major breakthrough in biology" refers to a discovery or development that fundamentally changes the understanding or application of biological sciences, and has a demonstrable impact on international relations, policies, or agreements. The influence on global politics must be confirmed by resolutions or official statements from international bodies (e.g., United Nations, World Health Organization), or by significant policy shifts in at least three G7 countries in response to the breakthrough. The breakthrough must be reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). Developments solely within medical treatment or technology, without broader political implications, do not qualify. In the event of ambiguity, the consensus among a panel of five experts in international relations and biology, as reported by a reputable news source, will be decisive.

title: Will the US Congress pass a significant new electoral reform bill by 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US Congress has passed a bill that significantly reforms the electoral process in the United States. Significant reform includes, but is not limited to, changes in voting methods, redistricting processes, campaign finance regulations, or the electoral college system. The bill must be signed into law by the President of the United States. 

For the purpose of this question, "significant" is defined as a reform that alters the electoral process in a way that is expected to have a substantial impact on future elections. The passage of the bill must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 

In the event that multiple bills are passed, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one of the bills meets the criteria for significant reform. Temporary measures or executive orders do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major tech company like Microsoft significantly influence a US election outcome by 2028?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, a major tech company (defined as a company with a market capitalization exceeding $500 billion USD as of 2023) like Microsoft is found to have significantly influenced the outcome of a United States federal election. Significant influence is defined as actions or interventions that directly affect the election results or voter turnout by at least 5 percentage points, as confirmed by a federal investigation or a consensus of at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post). Influence can include, but is not limited to, the dissemination of misinformation, targeted advertising based on user data, or the manipulation of search results or news feeds. Actions taken by subsidiaries or partners of the tech company that can be directly linked to the parent company's directives or policies will also count towards this question's resolution. In the absence of direct evidence, credible reports from major news organizations or non-partisan watchdog groups are sufficient. The question resolves as No if no such influence is confirmed by the resolution date.

title: Will a major political figure cite a scientific study related to black holes to emphasize the importance of space exploration within the next 5 years?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, a major political figure has publicly cited a scientific study related to black holes to emphasize the importance of space exploration. A "major political figure" is defined as a current or former head of state, government, or a member of the cabinet (or equivalent executive body) of any of the G20 countries. The citation must occur in a public speech, official statement, or published article. The scientific study must be identifiable and have been published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal. Verification will be based on reports from at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post).

title: Will a new political party focused on public health and immunology policies emerge in a G7 country before 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new political party with a primary focus on public health and immunology policies is officially registered and recognized in any of the G7 countries (Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States).

For the purpose of this question, a "new political party" is defined as a political organization that has not been previously registered as a political party in any jurisdiction and has public health and immunology as its central policy platform. The party must be officially recognized by the respective country's electoral or governmental body responsible for political party registration.

Recognition by major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or official government announcements will be considered sufficient evidence of the party's emergence. The party must have at least one candidate officially running for a national or significant regional office in an upcoming election to qualify.

In the event that multiple parties fitting the criteria emerge in different G7 countries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one of them meets all the specified criteria.

title: Will a major political figure propose a healthcare reform that significantly impacts the pharmaceutical industry by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure has proposed a healthcare reform that significantly impacts the pharmaceutical industry. A "major political figure" is defined as a current head of state, government, or a member of the legislative body in any of the G20 countries. The reform must propose changes that could lead to a significant shift in pharmaceutical industry practices, regulations, or market dynamics. Significant impact includes, but is not limited to, changes in drug pricing, patent laws, approval processes for new medications, or the introduction of universal healthcare systems that alter the pharmaceutical market. The proposal must be officially announced and documented. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary proposals or discussions that do not lead to formal legislative or executive action do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a political debate or policy directly impact the NBA's operations or player policies by 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a political debate or policy has directly impacted the operations or player policies of the National Basketball Association (NBA). Direct impact is defined as any of the following:
- Implementation of a new policy or amendment to existing policies by the NBA in response to a political debate or legislation.
- Public acknowledgment by the NBA of a change in operations or player policies due to political influence.
- Legislative or executive action at the federal or state level in the United States that specifically mandates changes in the NBA's operations or player policies.

For resolution, the impact must be confirmed by an official NBA announcement or documentation. In the absence of such an announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., ESPN, The New York Times, The Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary measures or policies implemented for less than a full NBA season do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will OpenAI's advancements lead to a significant policy change or regulation in AI governance by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, OpenAI's advancements in artificial intelligence have directly led to a significant policy change or the implementation of new regulations in AI governance. A "significant policy change or regulation" is defined as a new law, amendment, executive order, or international agreement that substantially alters the framework for AI development, deployment, or oversight. The change must be attributable to OpenAI's advancements, as evidenced by explicit mention in the policy document, official statements, or credible news reports from reputable sources such as BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, or Reuters. In the absence of direct evidence linking OpenAI to the policy change, a consensus among at least three reputable technology or policy analysis organizations that OpenAI's work was a key influencer will suffice. This question resolves as NO if such changes are proposed but not officially enacted by the resolution date.

title: Will a new political theory incorporating principles of string theory gain mainstream attention by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a new political theory that incorporates principles of string theory has gained mainstream attention. Mainstream attention is defined as the theory being featured in at least three of the following major media outlets: BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, or The Washington Post; or being the subject of discussion in at least five peer-reviewed academic journals in the fields of political science, international relations, or theoretical physics. The theory must explicitly reference string theory as a foundational element and apply its concepts to political structures, governance, or societal organization. In the event of ambiguity regarding the theory's incorporation of string theory or its level of attention, the question will resolve based on the consensus of experts in the fields of political science and theoretical physics.

title: Will China establish a new global alliance that significantly alters international relations by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the People's Republic of China has officially established a new global alliance that significantly alters international relations. The alliance must include at least five member countries, excluding China, and must be recognized as a formal international entity with a stated purpose of altering or significantly impacting global diplomatic, economic, or military dynamics. The establishment of the alliance must be confirmed by an official announcement from the Chinese government or the alliance itself. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The alliance must be new, not an expansion or rebranding of an existing alliance. In the event of a dispute over the significance of the alliance's impact on international relations, the consensus among at least three reputable international relations think tanks or academic institutions will be considered.

title: Will the European Union introduce a groundbreaking policy on digital privacy by 2025?
Will a major political figure propose significant reforms in pharmacology regulations by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure has publicly proposed significant reforms in pharmacology regulations. A "major political figure" is defined as a current head of state, government, or a minister of health (or equivalent position) in any of the G20 countries. "Significant reforms" are defined as proposed changes that would substantially alter the current pharmacology regulatory framework, including but not limited to drug approval processes, pricing, distribution, and safety standards. The proposal must be detailed enough to suggest a clear plan of action and must be made in an official capacity, either through a public announcement, official government documentation, or a speech in a significant legislative body. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. In the event that multiple figures propose reforms, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first verified proposal.

title: Will a political figure announce a collaboration with SpaceX on a space policy initiative by 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, a current or former political figure publicly announces a collaboration with SpaceX on a space policy initiative. The announcement must be made through official channels (e.g., press release, official social media accounts, public speech) or confirmed by SpaceX. The political figure must have held or currently hold a significant governmental or legislative position (e.g., President, Prime Minister, Senator, Member of Parliament). Collaborations that are purely commercial or private ventures without a clear policy objective do not count towards this question's resolution. In the absence of a direct announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient for resolution. The initiative must aim at shaping or influencing space exploration, technology development, or regulatory frameworks.

title: Will a new political party with a focus on environmental and biological conservation gain parliamentary seats in a major country by 2026?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, a new political party with a primary focus on environmental and biological conservation gains one or more seats in the national parliament of any of the following countries: United States, China, India, Germany, United Kingdom, France, Brazil, or Russia.

A "new political party" is defined as a party officially registered after January 1, 2021. Gaining a seat refers to winning in a national parliamentary election, not through defection or realignment of existing parliament members.

The confirmation of the party gaining seats must come from official election results published by the national electoral commission or equivalent authority of the respective country. In the absence of direct confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient.

In the event that multiple new parties meet the criteria, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one of them gains a parliamentary seat.

title: Will a major political figure announce a significant policy change regarding public health and virology research funding by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure (defined as a current head of state, government, or a minister of health) in any of the G7 countries (United States, United Kingdom, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan) announces a significant policy change regarding public health and virology research funding. A "significant policy change" is defined as a change that results in an increase or decrease of at least 20% in the allocated funding compared to the previous fiscal year, or the establishment of a new, dedicated funding program for virology research. The announcement must be made through official government channels or documented in reputable news sources such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, or Washington Post. In the absence of a clear announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations are sufficient. Temporary measures or emergency funding in response to specific outbreaks do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a candidate from the Democratic Party win the 2024 US Presidential Election?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if a candidate from the Democratic Party wins the 2024 US Presidential Election. The outcome will be determined based on the official results as certified by the United States Electoral College. In the event of any disputes, recounts, or legal challenges, the question will resolve based on the final, certified election results. If no candidate from the Democratic Party is officially declared the winner by the Electoral College, the question will resolve as No. For the purpose of this question, a "win" is defined as the candidate from the Democratic Party receiving the majority of electoral votes.

title: Will a political campaign in the 2024 US elections prominently feature sports development policies, specifically focusing on basketball?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, a political campaign for any major federal office in the 2024 US elections (President, Senate, or House of Representatives) prominently features sports development policies with a specific focus on basketball. 

Prominently featuring means that the policy must be included in the official campaign platform, mentioned in multiple major campaign speeches, or detailed in campaign literature. 

For the purpose of this question, 'sports development policies' are defined as policies aimed at promoting, funding, or otherwise supporting the development of sports, with a particular emphasis on basketball. This can include, but is not limited to, funding for youth basketball programs, infrastructure development like basketball courts, or initiatives to support professional or amateur basketball leagues. 

The campaign must be for a candidate who is officially nominated by their party. Self-declared candidates without official party nomination do not count. 

Confirmation must come from official campaign materials or coverage in at least two major news organizations (e.g., CNN, Fox News, The New York Times, The Washington Post).

title: Will South Korea elect a female president by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea has officially elected a female president. The election must be recognized as legitimate by the National Election Commission of South Korea. Confirmation of the election result must come from official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a direct government announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Interim or acting presidents do not count towards this question's resolution, unless they are elected to the position in a subsequent election.

title: Will the United Nations implement a new global environmental policy by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United Nations has officially implemented a new global environmental policy. The policy must be aimed at addressing at least one of the following areas: climate change, biodiversity loss, water scarcity, pollution, or sustainable development. Implementation is defined as the policy being formally adopted and announced by the United Nations through an official document or press release. The policy must be actionable, with clear goals, timelines, and mechanisms for enforcement or assessment. In the absence of a direct announcement, confirmation from at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence of implementation. Temporary measures or policies that are only proposed or in draft form will not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major political party in a G20 country adopt a policy platform focused on combating climate change by 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, any major political party in a G20 country officially adopts a policy platform that is primarily focused on combating climate change. A "major political party" is defined as one that holds or has held government office or is the primary opposition in its respective country. The policy platform must include specific measures aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, promoting renewable energy sources, and addressing the impacts of climate change. The adoption of the policy platform must be confirmed through official party documentation or a public announcement. In the absence of direct confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The policy platform must represent a significant shift towards climate change mitigation and adaptation, rather than a minor update to existing policies. In the event of ambiguity regarding the focus of the policy platform, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will Major League Baseball influence any major political decisions or legislation in the next five years?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, Major League Baseball (MLB) is directly cited as having influenced any major political decisions or legislation in the United States. Influence is defined as MLB's explicit endorsement, lobbying efforts, or public statements that are directly linked to the drafting, amendment, or passage of legislation at the federal, state, or local level. The influence must be confirmed by official government records, such as legislative documents, hearing transcripts, or public statements by lawmakers. In the absence of direct government documentation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, Washington Post, The Guardian) will be considered sufficient. The decision or legislation must have significant national or state-level impact, as determined by its coverage in major media outlets. Temporary measures or resolutions without lasting legal effects do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will California pass significant new climate change legislation before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, California passes new legislation that significantly advances the state's climate change policies or goals. Significant legislation is defined as any law or set of laws that result in a measurable reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, promote substantial renewable energy adoption, enhance energy efficiency across major sectors, or provide significant funding for climate change mitigation or adaptation efforts. The legislation must be passed by the California State Legislature and signed into law by the Governor. Confirmation of such legislation will be based on official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (Los Angeles Times, San Francisco Chronicle, The New York Times, The Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary measures or executive orders do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will Sweden host a major international political summit by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Sweden has officially hosted a major international political summit. A "major international political summit" is defined as a meeting that includes heads of state or government from at least five countries, focusing on significant global or regional issues, and receiving widespread coverage in major international news outlets such as BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, and Reuters. The summit must be recognized by the United Nations or a similar international body as being of significant international importance. In the event of a virtual summit due to unforeseen circumstances (e.g., a pandemic), the question will still resolve as Yes, provided the other criteria are met. Temporary, informal, or emergency meetings do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will Norway apply for EU membership before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Norway officially applies for membership in the European Union. An official application is defined as the submission of a formal request by the Norwegian government to the European Union Council, confirmed by an official statement from either the Norwegian government or the European Union. In the absence of an official statement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient to confirm the application. The question will resolve as No if no such application is made by the specified date. Temporary or exploratory discussions, as well as public or political declarations of intent without a formal application, do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will South Korea announce a significant shift in its North Korea policy before 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the South Korean government officially announces a significant shift in its policy towards North Korea. A "significant shift" is defined as any of the following:
- Official declaration of a change in military posture or engagement rules.
- Announcement of major economic sanctions or the lifting thereof.
- Initiation of significant diplomatic negotiations aimed at peace, reunification, or mutual defense agreements.
- Public declaration of support for or opposition to North Korean leadership in a manner markedly different from previous positions.
The announcement must be confirmed by an official government statement or press release. In the absence of a direct government announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary measures or statements in response to specific incidents do not qualify as a significant shift for the purposes of this question's resolution.

title: Will Switzerland implement a groundbreaking digital governance initiative by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Switzerland has officially implemented a digital governance initiative that is recognized as groundbreaking. A "groundbreaking digital governance initiative" is defined as a program or policy that significantly alters the way government services are delivered, enhances the efficiency of public administration, or substantially improves citizen engagement through the use of digital technology. The initiative must be the first of its kind in Switzerland and should serve as a model for other countries. The implementation of such an initiative must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The initiative must be fully operational and not in a pilot or trial phase. In the event of a partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific regions or aspects of governance), the question will resolve as Yes if the initiative is intended for nationwide application.

title: Will Russia face new international sanctions related to election interference before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, Russia faces new international sanctions specifically related to election interference. The sanctions must be imposed by any of the following entities: the United Nations, the European Union, the United States, or a coalition of countries from the G7. The sanctions must be in response to actions taken to interfere in foreign elections and must be confirmed by official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. Sanctions imposed for reasons other than election interference, such as human rights violations or military aggression, do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major political party propose legislation to regulate large tech companies like Amazon by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political party in any of the G7 countries (United States, United Kingdom, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan) officially proposes legislation aimed at regulating large tech companies, including but not limited to Amazon. The legislation must specifically target issues related to market dominance, data privacy, or antitrust concerns. The proposal must be formally introduced in the national legislature or officially announced by the party. Confirmation from at least two reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, Reuters) is required for resolution. Proposals focused solely on tax policy or minor regulatory adjustments without addressing the core issues of market dominance, data privacy, or antitrust will not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will an NHL team visit the White House to celebrate a championship victory before the end of 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2026, any NHL team visits the White House in Washington, D.C., to celebrate a championship victory. The visit must be officially recognized by either the White House or the NHL team involved. Confirmation can come from official statements, press releases, or coverage by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., ESPN, Sports Illustrated, The New York Times, The Washington Post). Visits for reasons other than celebrating a championship victory, such as community outreach or personal invitations, do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a major political party in the United States propose significant legislation regarding information technology and privacy before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major political party in the United States (defined as the Democratic Party or the Republican Party) officially proposes significant legislation regarding information technology and privacy. Significant legislation is defined as a bill or resolution introduced in either the United States Senate or House of Representatives that aims to substantially alter the legal framework governing information technology, data privacy, or cybersecurity. The proposal must seek to introduce new regulations or significantly amend existing laws. Confirmation of such a proposal must come from official government publications or statements. In the absence of direct government confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. Proposals that only marginally adjust current laws or are limited to non-binding resolutions do not meet the criteria for significant legislation. In the event of multiple proposals, the question will resolve as Yes upon the first proposal meeting these criteria.

title: Will the Bureau of Labor Statistics release a report by 2025 indicating a major shift in employment trends due to political decisions?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) releases a report that indicates a major shift in employment trends directly attributed to political decisions made in the United States. A "major shift" is defined as a change in employment rates by more than 5% in any sector or overall unemployment rates by more than 2% compared to the previous year. The report must explicitly attribute these changes to specific political decisions or policies. Verification will be based on the official BLS report. In the absence of such a report, credible coverage from at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post) reporting on BLS data or analysis that confirms these criteria will also be considered sufficient for resolution. The question will resolve as No if these conditions are not met by the specified date.

title: Will a political figure be officially involved in the opening ceremony of the next Olympics?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by the opening ceremony of the next Olympic Games, an individual holding a current political office at any level (local, regional, national, or international) is officially involved in the ceremony. Official involvement includes, but is not limited to, speaking roles, participation in the torch relay, or any form of ceremonial duty recognized by the Olympic Committee. The involvement must be documented by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) or reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post).

title: Will SpaceX launch a mission that is directly funded by a government for a political purpose by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, SpaceX has launched a mission that is directly funded by a government for a political purpose. A "political purpose" is defined as any mission aimed at achieving specific political objectives, such as demonstrating technological superiority, diplomatic signaling, or strategic deployment of space assets. The funding and purpose of the mission must be confirmed through official government documentation or announcements. In the absence of direct government confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) will be considered sufficient evidence. The mission must be completed, not merely announced or in planning stages. In the event of ambiguity regarding the mission's political purpose, a consensus among reputable news sources or official government statements will be used to determine the outcome.

title: Will Google face antitrust legislation in the United States that significantly alters its business operations by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Google faces antitrust legislation in the United States that significantly alters its business operations. Significant alteration includes, but is not limited to, forced divestiture of assets, changes in operational practices mandated by law, or substantial financial penalties directly related to antitrust concerns. The legislation must be passed by the United States Congress and signed into law by the President, or enacted through a final court decision. Confirmation must come from official government sources or be reported by at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post, Reuters). In the event of ambiguous outcomes, such as proposed but not enacted legislation, or minor adjustments not considered significant, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will China introduce a new major policy initiative aimed at reducing carbon emissions before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the People's Republic of China officially announces a new major policy initiative aimed at significantly reducing carbon emissions. The policy must represent a substantial change or addition to existing policies and have a clear implementation timeline and targets for emission reductions. The announcement must come from an official government source or be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). In the event of ambiguous announcements, the question will resolve as Yes only if the policy is implemented and in effect by the resolution date.
