Temporary measures or policies with minor impact on overall carbon emissions will not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will Scott Alexander, or a similarly prominent public intellectual, announce a run for political office in the United States before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, Scott Alexander or a similarly prominent public intellectual announces their candidacy for any political office in the United States. For the purpose of this question, a "similarly prominent public intellectual" is defined as an individual widely recognized for their contributions to public discourse through writing, speaking, or other forms of media, and who has a significant following on major social media platforms or traditional media outlets. The announcement must be verifiable through an official campaign announcement or coverage by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of ambiguity regarding the individual's prominence or the authenticity of the announcement, the resolution will default to No.

title: Will a significant political movement or party emerge with a focus on space exploration policies by 2030?
Will a major political figure propose a groundbreaking climate change policy that gains international support by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure proposes a climate change policy that is considered groundbreaking and gains explicit support from at least five different countries' governments. The policy must represent a significant departure from current climate policies and aim to substantially reduce carbon emissions or mitigate climate change effects on a global scale. Groundbreaking is defined as introducing new methods, ideas, or products that have a significant and positive impact on global climate change efforts. International support must be confirmed through official statements, agreements, or endorsements from the governments involved. In the absence of direct government statements, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence of international support. The proposal must be made by a figure who holds or has held a significant political office (e.g., President, Prime Minister, Secretary-General of the United Nations) at the time of the proposal. Policies proposed in international forums, such as the United Nations Climate Change Conference, are included. In the event of multiple proposals meeting these criteria, the question will resolve as Yes at the first instance of such a proposal.

title: Will a new political ideology centered around genetic engineering ethics and regulations gain prominence by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new political ideology that is primarily focused on the ethics and regulations of genetic engineering gains prominence. "Prominence" is defined as the ideology being officially recognized by at least one national government as a basis for legislation, policy-making, or political party formation; or being the subject of significant academic discussion in at least three peer-reviewed journals in the fields of political science, bioethics, or genetic engineering. The ideology must explicitly address the ethical implications, societal impacts, and regulatory considerations of genetic engineering on humans, animals, or both. In the absence of government recognition, significant coverage in at least three reputable news sources (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) will also be considered sufficient evidence of prominence. The ideology must be distinct and primarily focused on genetic engineering ethics and regulations, rather than being a subset of existing political ideologies.

title: Will a significant political figure from a UN member state publicly endorse a new pharmacological policy to address a global health issue by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a significant political figure from a UN member state publicly endorses a new pharmacological policy aimed at addressing a global health issue. A "significant political figure" is defined as a current head of state, head of government, health minister, or equivalent position. The endorsement must be explicit, public, and related to a new policy proposal or implementation that has not been previously enacted or proposed by the government of the respective UN member state. The policy must be aimed at addressing a global health issue, such as a pandemic, widespread disease, or significant health crisis affecting multiple countries. The endorsement must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or through an official government press release. In the event of ambiguous or conflicting reports, the resolution will default to No unless clear evidence is provided.

title: Will the United Nations introduce a resolution to address the impact of climate change on global political stability before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the United Nations officially introduces a resolution specifically aimed at addressing the impact of climate change on global political stability. The resolution must be introduced in an official UN session and aim to mitigate, discuss, or address the effects of climate change on global political stability, including but not limited to, conflict, migration, and economic disparities. The introduction of the resolution must be confirmed by an official UN announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary measures or discussions not resulting in the introduction of a formal resolution do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will Scott Alexander publish an essay that significantly influences a political election or policy by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Scott Alexander (author of the blog Slate Star Codex, now known as Astral Codex Ten) has published an essay that is directly cited by elected officials, political candidates, or major policy-making bodies as having significantly influenced their decision-making process or the outcome of a political election. Significant influence is defined as the essay being a key factor in the development, proposal, or enactment of legislation, policy changes, or the strategy of a political campaign. Verification of influence must come from public statements, interviews, or official documents. In the absence of direct citations, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the essay's influence are sufficient. The essay must be published on Astral Codex Ten or a platform of similar repute. Essays published under pseudonyms or anonymously must be verifiably attributed to Scott Alexander to count.

title: Will Japan pass a major constitutional amendment by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Japan has officially passed a major constitutional amendment. A "major constitutional amendment" is defined as any change to the Japanese Constitution that alters the structure of government, the balance of powers, the rights of citizens, or the official pacifist stance of the country. The passage of the amendment must be confirmed through official government channels, including but not limited to, an announcement from the Prime Minister's office, the National Diet's official record, or the official gazette of Japan. In the absence of direct government confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (NHK, The Japan Times, Asahi Shimbun, Yomiuri Shimbun, or international equivalents such as BBC, The New York Times) will be considered sufficient. In the event of ambiguity regarding the significance of the amendment, the consensus among these news sources will be used to determine its major status. Temporary measures, emergency declarations, or amendments that do not alter the Constitution's core principles do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a significant political figure publicly endorse string theory as a basis for policy by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a significant political figure publicly endorses string theory as a basis for policy. A "significant political figure" is defined as a current or former head of state, government, or a member of the national legislature in any of the G20 countries. The endorsement must be explicit, referring to string theory by name, and suggest its application or influence on policy making. The endorsement must be made in a public forum, such as an official speech, published article, or a verified social media post. In the absence of direct evidence, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient. The policy area influenced by string theory does not need to be specified for the question to resolve as Yes. In the event of ambiguity, the consensus of coverage by the specified news organizations will determine the resolution.

title: Will the United Kingdom hold another referendum on Scottish independence by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United Kingdom has officially announced and scheduled a referendum on Scottish independence. The announcement must come from a recognized authority within the UK government, such as the Prime Minister's Office, the Parliament, or the Scottish Government. The referendum must be intended to be held on or before December 31, 2025. In the absence of an official government announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the scheduling of the referendum will be sufficient for resolution. Temporary or speculative announcements without a set date do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will Mexico introduce a major electoral reform that impacts its political landscape by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Mexico has officially introduced a major electoral reform that significantly impacts its political landscape. A "major electoral reform" is defined as any change in the electoral system, voting process, or political representation structure that alters the way elections are conducted or how representatives are chosen in a manner that could significantly affect the outcome of future elections. The reform must be enacted into law by the Mexican government and recognized as "major" by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, El País). In the event of ambiguous reforms, the question will resolve based on the consensus of political analysts from at least three reputable institutions. Temporary measures or reforms limited to specific regions or electoral districts do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will a significant political event be influenced by an astronomical phenomenon by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a significant political event is directly influenced by an astronomical phenomenon. A "significant political event" is defined as an event that results in a major change in leadership, policy, or national borders in any country recognized by the United Nations. An "astronomical phenomenon" refers to events such as solar eclipses, comets visible to the naked eye, meteor showers, or planetary alignments. The influence must be explicitly acknowledged by at least one of the involved parties' official communications or by credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). The influence of the astronomical phenomenon on the political event must be clear and direct, not merely coincidental or ceremonial. In the event of ambiguity, a panel of experts in political science and astronomy, as reported by the aforementioned news organizations, will be consulted to determine the resolution.

title: Will a major political figure in the US publicly endorse the NBA as a tool for social change by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure in the United States has publicly endorsed the National Basketball Association (NBA) as a tool for social change. For the purposes of this question, a "major political figure" is defined as a current or former President, Vice President, member of the U.S. Cabinet, U.S. Senator, or U.S. Representative. The endorsement must be explicit, referring directly to the NBA's role or potential in driving social change, and must be made in a public forum such as an official speech, published op-ed, or a verified social media post. In the event of ambiguous statements, the resolution will require confirmation through a follow-up statement or clarification by the political figure in question. The endorsement must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post).

title: Will the Virginia Department of Health implement a new public health policy addressing climate change impacts by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Virginia Department of Health has officially implemented a new public health policy specifically addressing the impacts of climate change. The policy must be designed to mitigate health risks associated with climate change, such as increased heatwaves, vector-borne diseases, air quality issues, and waterborne diseases. The implementation of such a policy must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post) are sufficient. The policy must be in effect, not merely proposed or in a planning stage. In the event of a partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific regions within Virginia), the question will resolve as Yes if the policy is intended for statewide application.

title: Will a major political figure propose legislation to regulate genetic editing technologies by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major political figure has proposed legislation to regulate genetic editing technologies. A "major political figure" is defined as a current head of state, government, or a member of the legislative body in any of the G20 countries. The proposed legislation must specifically address the use, research, development, or ethical implications of genetic editing technologies, including but not limited to CRISPR-Cas9. The proposal must be officially presented or announced in a legislative body or through an official government channel. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) are sufficient to confirm the proposal. The legislation does not need to be passed or come into effect for the question to resolve as Yes.

Will a political campaign in the United States utilize machine learning algorithms to significantly improve voter turnout by 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, a political campaign within the United States has utilized machine learning algorithms in a manner that significantly improves voter turnout. Significant improvement is defined as an increase in voter turnout by at least 5% compared to the previous similar election cycle (e.g., presidential to presidential, midterm to midterm) for the targeted demographic or area. The use of machine learning algorithms must be documented and verified through either an official campaign announcement, credible media reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., CNN, The New York Times, The Washington Post), or peer-reviewed academic publications. The algorithms must be used specifically for voter engagement, targeting, or turnout strategies. In the event of multiple campaigns meeting these criteria, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one campaign's efforts are independently verified to have met the significant improvement threshold.

title: Will a political campaign in the United States utilize machine learning algorithms to significantly improve voter turnout by 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, a political campaign within the United States has utilized machine learning algorithms in a manner that significantly improves voter turnout. Significant improvement is defined as an increase in voter turnout by at least 5% compared to the previous similar election cycle (e.g., presidential to presidential, midterm to midterm) within the same jurisdiction. The use of machine learning algorithms must be documented and confirmed through either an official campaign announcement or credible media reports from at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post). The improvement in voter turnout must be attributed directly to the use of machine learning algorithms by the campaign, as evidenced by voter data analysis or an independent study.

title: Will Joe Biden run for a second term in the next presidential election?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if Joe Biden officially announces his candidacy for a second term in the next U.S. presidential election, or if the Democratic National Committee (DNC) officially nominates him as their candidate for the presidency. The announcement or nomination must be confirmed by Joe Biden himself, the DNC, or through an official campaign statement. In the absence of a direct announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, Washington Post, CNN, or Reuters) will be considered sufficient. This question resolves as NO if Joe Biden publicly announces that he will not run, or if the DNC nominates another candidate without Biden having made any prior announcement regarding his candidacy. In the event of Joe Biden's inability to run due to health issues or other unforeseen circumstances, the question will also resolve as NO.

title: Will a major political figure propose a significant increase in aerospace engineering funding by 2024?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, a major political figure has publicly proposed a significant increase in aerospace engineering funding. A "major political figure" is defined as a current head of state, government, or a minister of finance, defense, or science and technology of any of the G20 countries. A "significant increase" is defined as a proposed funding increase of at least 20% from the current levels or a specific proposal amounting to at least $1 billion USD in additional funds, whichever is lower. The proposal must be made in an official capacity and reported by at least two reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). Proposals made in personal capacities or unofficial remarks do not count towards this question's resolution.
